Increasing which of the following substances in his diet is most likely to help a patient with PDH deficiency generate energy without further elevating lactate levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lysine

 

In pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) deficiency, pyruvate cannot be converted to acetyl-CoA, leading to accumulation of pyruvate and its conversion to lactate, causing lactic acidosis. To avoid worsening lactate buildup, patients must rely on energy sources that bypass glycolysis and pyruvate metabolism. Lysine (and leucine) are purely ketogenic amino acids, meaning they are metabolized directly into acetyl-CoA or acetoacetate without forming pyruvate. Thus, increasing lysine intake provides an alternate energy source while avoiding lactate accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine: Incorrect. Alanine is glucogenic; it is transaminated to pyruvate, which would worsen lactate buildup in PDH deficiency.

 

Option B. Asparagine: Incorrect. Asparagine is glucogenic, converting to oxaloacetate and eventually to pyruvate or glucose, again feeding into the pathway that increases lactate levels.

 

Option C. Glycerol: Incorrect. Glycerol enters gluconeogenesis via glycerol-3-phosphate → dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP), which can also increase pyruvate production and, consequently, lactate levels.

choices.text: It alters the maximal velocity of the reaction

questions.text: Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) is an enzyme complex located within the inner mitochondrial membrane that catalyses the oxidation of succinate to fumarate. An experiment is conducted to determine if malate alters the rate of SDH activity. Reaction velocity is measured with and without a fixed quantity of malate as succinate concentration is gradually increased. Which of the following is the most accurate statement about malate in this experiment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme

 

The data provided describe an enzyme kinetics experiment with succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) — a key enzyme in both the TCA cycle and the electron transport chain.

 

It catalyzes:

 

 

Malate, a structurally related intermediate of the same pathway, is tested for its effect on SDH activity.

 

Observed Data Pattern:

 

 

Key Observations:

 

  1. At low succinate concentrations (2–16 mM):
    The presence of malate reduces the reaction rate.
  2. At high succinate concentrations (64–128 mM):
    The rates are identical with or without malate (Vmax = 400 µmol/L/sec).

 

This means that the maximum velocity (Vmax) is unchanged, but the substrate concentration required to reach half-maximal velocity (Km) is increased in the presence of malate.

 

Interpretation:

 

This pattern —

 

  • Unchanged Vmax,
  • Increased Km,
    is the hallmark of competitive inhibition.

 

Mechanistic Explanation:

 

  • Competitive inhibitors resemble the substrate’s structure and compete for the enzyme’s active site.
  • Their inhibitory effect can be overcome by increasing substrate concentration — as seen in this experiment when succinate concentration increases, malate’s effect disappears.
  • Hence, malate competes directly with succinate for SDH’s active site.

 


Other Options:

 

Option A. It alters the maximal velocity of the reaction: Incorrect.

 

  • Vmax remains unchanged (400 µmol/L/sec).
  • Only noncompetitive inhibitors alter Vmax.

 

Option B. It binds the enzyme at a different site than succinate: Incorrect. That describes noncompetitive/allosteric inhibition.

 

Option C. It decreases affinity of the enzyme for succinate: While apparent affinity (Km) is decreased, this is the mechanistic result of competitive inhibition.

 

  • The more precise description is that malate is a competitive inhibitor, not just that it “decreases affinity.”

 

Although Option C seems correct, the most accurate statement [answer] is Option D.

A 45-year-old homeless man comes to the emergency department due to a "pins-and-needles" sensation in his legs. He also has painful lesions on his lips and corners of his mouth. Abdominal examination reveals hepatomegaly. Laboratory evaluation shows very low urinary riboflavin excretion. Activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely directly impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Succinate dehydrogenase

 

The patient shows clinical features of riboflavin (vitamin B₂) deficiency, such as angular cheilitis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis, along with low urinary riboflavin excretion. Riboflavin is a precursor of flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and flavin mononucleotide (FMN), both essential cofactors for various oxidative enzymes. Succinate dehydrogenase, a key enzyme in the TCA cycle and the electron transport chain (complex II), specifically requires FAD as a cofactor to oxidize succinate to fumarate. Hence, its activity is directly impaired in riboflavin deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase: Uses NADP⁺ as a cofactor, not FAD or FMN. It catalyzes the first step of the pentose phosphate pathway and is unaffected by riboflavin deficiency.

 

Option B. HMG-CoA reductase: Catalyzes the rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis and requires NADPH, not FAD or FMN, for its reductive biosynthetic function.

 

Option C. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Requires NAD⁺ or NADP⁺ as cofactors, not flavin derivatives. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate in the TCA cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The mRNA for the Transferrin receptor is not bound by IRP and is rapidly degraded.

 

Concept Overview: Iron Homeostasis & IRE–IRP Regulation

 

Iron metabolism in cells is tightly regulated post-transcriptionally by the interaction of Iron Regulatory Proteins (IRPs) with Iron-Responsive Elements (IREs) on specific mRNAs.

 

These control the synthesis of:

 

  • Transferrin receptor (TfR) → promotes iron uptake
  • Ferritin (apoferritin) → promotes iron storage

 

Mechanism:

 

 

In Hemochromatosis:

 

  • Iron overload → High intracellular iron levels
  • High iron causes IRPs to lose affinity for IREs (they become inactivated by iron–sulfur cluster formation).
  • Therefore:
    • Transferrin receptor mRNA (which has IREs in its 3′ UTR) is not protected → degraded → ↓ TfR.
    • Ferritin mRNA (which has IREs in its 5′ UTR) is translated freely → ↑ ferritin.

 

This decreases further iron uptake and increases storage — a homeostatic response to excess iron.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is produced in increased amounts than normal in the liver of a patient with lead toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ALA synthase

 

Lead (Pb²⁺) toxicity interferes with heme synthesis by inhibiting key enzymes in the heme biosynthetic pathway.


When heme production is inhibited, the liver compensates by upregulating ALA synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme of the pathway.

 

 

Mechanism in Lead Poisoning:

 

  1. Lead inhibits:
    • ALA dehydratase → accumulation of δ-ALA
    • Ferrochelatase  → prevents insertion of Fe²⁺ into protoporphyrin IX → free protoporphyrin accumulates
  2. ↓ Heme synthesis → ↓ intracellular heme
  3. Low heme → loss of negative feedback inhibition on ALA synthase (the first enzyme)
  4. The liver compensates by increasing ALA synthase production to restore heme synthesis — but this fails due to the block downstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heme oxygenase: 

 

  • Catalyzes degradation of heme → biliverdin → bilirubin.
  • Activity decreases when heme levels fall. Not induced by lead toxicity.

 

Option C. Ferrochelatase:

 

  • Inhibited by lead. Responsible for inserting Fe²⁺ into protoporphyrin IX.
  • Lead binds sulfhydryl groups and displaces zinc → enzyme inhibition.

 

Option D. Porphobilinogen deaminase:

 

  • Deficiency causes Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP), not lead poisoning.
  • Not affected or induced by lead.

A 16-year-old patient happens to have pellagra-like eruptions on skin in spring season from the last 5 years with normal HIAA and high aminoaciduria. Indole levels in urine are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hartnup disease

 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in the absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids in the intestine and renal tubules. This defect leads to increased excretion of amino acids in the urine, known as aminoaciduria. Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin (Vitamin B3) synthesis, and its deficiency can lead to pellagra-like symptoms, including dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often referred to as the "3 D's" of pellagra.

 

In this case, the patient presents with pellagra-like eruptions and high aminoaciduria. The normal HIAA levels rule out a carcinoid tumor, which would show elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to increased serotonin production. The absence of dietary history indicative of niacin or tryptophan deficiency (as seen in nutritional pellagra) further supports Hartnup disease as the diagnosis. Additionally, essential fructosuria is a benign condition and does not cause skin eruptions or pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Note –

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid with a bulky indole ring side chain.
  • 60 mg of tryptophan converts into 1 mg of niacin
  • Best Treatment of Niacin deficiency - Niacin or nicotinamide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid syndrome would typically present with elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to excessive conversion of tryptophan to serotonin. The normal HIAA levels in this patient make carcinoid tumor an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Nutritional pellagra: This condition is due to a dietary deficiency of niacin (Vitamin B3) or its precursor tryptophan. However, the patient does not present with a history of dietary deficiency, and the high aminoaciduria suggests an alternative diagnosis.

 

Option D. Essential fructosuria: This condition is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme fructokinase, leading to fructose excretion in urine. However, it is asymptomatic and does not cause skin eruptions or any pellagra-like symptoms, making it an incorrect answer in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra or pellagra like symptoms can result from (Differential Diagnosis):

 

  • Niacin (B3) deficiency due to a diet high in maize, which is low in tryptophan.
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency, since the enzyme kynureninase, which catalyzes a step in niacin synthesis from tryptophan, requires B6 as a cofactor. B6 deficiency also leads to increased synthesis of xanthurenic acid
  • Carcinoid syndrome: can be differentiated with elevated HIAA level with pellagra like symptoms.
  • Hartnup disease can present with pellagra-like symptoms due to defective absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids, leading to high aminoaciduria and niacin deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following can be mediated by CRISPR CAS 9 technology? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA editing

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is a powerful tool used for DNA editing. It works by creating double-strand breaks in the DNA at specific locations. The CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats) component guides the Cas9 endonuclease to the precise cutting site within the genome. Once the DNA is cut, the cell’s natural repair mechanisms are used to add, delete, or replace genetic material at the targeted site, enabling precise editing of the DNA sequence.

 

CRISPR-Cas9 is derived from a natural immune system in bacteria, which uses this mechanism to defend against bacteriophages by cutting their DNA. In genetic engineering, this system has been harnessed for various applications, including gene deletion, exogenous gene insertion, and multigene editing, all of which involve altering the DNA sequence in a targeted manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA replication: CRISPR-Cas9 does not play a role in DNA replication, which is the process by which DNA is copied before cell division. DNA replication is managed by other cellular machinery, including DNA polymerases.

 

Option B. Post-transcriptional modification: This involves changes to RNA after it has been transcribed from DNA, such as splicing, editing, or polyadenylation. CRISPR-Cas9 does not mediate these processes; it specifically targets DNA.

 

Option C. DNA induction: This term is not commonly used in the context of molecular biology, and it does not apply to CRISPR-Cas9 technology. CRISPR-Cas9 is specifically used for editing DNA, not for inducing or initiating processes within the DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is primarily used for precise DNA editing, enabling targeted modifications to the genetic code

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for sample collection in a tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium dichromate

 

Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) can be measured through various methods, including gas chromatography. For accurate measurement of BAC, the blood sample is typically collected in a gray-top vial. This vial contains a mixture of sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate.

 

Sodium fluoride acts as a preservative and prevents glycolysis, which could otherwise lower the concentration of alcohol in the blood sample.

 

However, when using the potassium dichromate test for BAC, potassium dichromate is included in the sample collection tube. In this test, potassium dichromate, which is orange in color, reacts with ethanol present in the blood sample. This reaction converts ethanol to acetic acid and simultaneously reduces potassium dichromate to chromium, which turns the solution green. The intensity of the green color directly correlates with the alcohol concentration in the sample, providing a visual indication of BAC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin + EDTA: This combination is generally used as an anticoagulant in blood samples for various laboratory tests but is not specifically used for BAC measurement.

 

Option C. Heparin: While heparin is an anticoagulant, it is not used in the collection tubes for blood alcohol concentration testing.

 

Option D. Sodium citrate: Sodium citrate is also an anticoagulant, commonly used in coagulation studies, but it is not relevant for BAC measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement. Potassium dichromate reacts with ethanol in the blood sample, facilitating the detection and quantification of alcohol concentration

questions.text: Researchers isolate small circular DNA molecules from pancreatic cells that resemble a bacterial chromosome. Further analysis shows that these molecules code for proteins, transfer RNA, and ribosomal RNA. From which of the following cellular structures did these DNA molecules most likely originate?
Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine poisoning

 

Gastric lavage, also known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, involves the removal of the stomach's contents via a tube. It is contraindicated in certain situations due to the risks involved.

 

Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine is a convulsive poison. Performing gastric lavage on a patient with strychnine poisoning is highly dangerous because it can induce further convulsions and seizures. Gastric lavage acts as a stimulus, which can exacerbate the convulsions, leading to a higher risk of complications including aspiration of stomach contents into the lungs.

 

Contraindications of gastric lavage:

 

  • Corrosive substances (an absolute C/I): Risk of gastric perforation except for carbolic acid, which hardens the stomach wall.
  • Convulsive patients: Risk of aspiration.
  • Comatose patients: Also at risk of aspiration unless the airway is protected.
  • Kerosene & other volatile poison, including hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons are volatile and can cause chemical pneumonitis if aspirated.
  • Oesophageal Varices

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ingestion of paraldehyde: Paraldehyde ingestion does not have the same risk of inducing convulsions or seizures. Gastric lavage can be considered in some cases, but it is not absolutely contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ingestion of hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons, such as kerosene, are volatile and pose a high risk of aspiration leading to chemical pneumonitis. While this is also a contraindication, the most critical contraindication here is strychnine poisoning due to the additional risk of inducing seizures.

 

Option D. Iron tablet ingestion: Iron tablets do not pose a high risk of convulsions or severe aspiration. Gastric lavage can be used in cases of iron tablet ingestion if done early and under proper medical supervision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in cases of strychnine poisoning due to the high risk of inducing further convulsions and seizures, which can exacerbate the patient's condition.

questions.text: Which drug would be most effective in preventing withdrawal symptoms in a patient with a history of alcohol consumption who was admitted to the hospital after a road traffic accident? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Alcohol withdrawal can present with symptoms like anxiety, tremors, seizures, and delirium tremens, which can be life-threatening. Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, work by enhancing the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA, which has a calming effect on the nervous system, thereby reducing the risk of withdrawal symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This drug is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, not for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reduce cravings and prevent relapse in patients recovering from alcohol or opioid dependence. It is not used to manage acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic used for the management of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). It is not effective for treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the drugs of choice to prevent and manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of breast cancer. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of which nucleotide? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TMP

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate drug that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). This enzyme is critical in the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, a precursor needed for the de novo synthesis of thymidylate (dTMP). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate leads to a decrease in thymine monophosphate (TMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis and repair. This inhibition ultimately impedes the proliferation of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, making methotrexate effective in the treatment of breast cancer and other malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AMP: Adenosine monophosphate is not directly affected by methotrexate. Methotrexate does not inhibit the synthesis of purine nucleotides like AMP.

 

Option B. CMP: Cytidine monophosphate is a pyrimidine nucleotide, but its synthesis is not directly impacted by methotrexate.

 

Option C. UMP: Uridine monophosphate is another pyrimidine nucleotide that is not directly influenced by methotrexate's mechanism of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to a reduction in thymine monophosphate (TMP) synthesis, which is critical for DNA synthesis. This makes it effective in the treatment of cancers, including breast cancer

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was initially being treated with sertraline, but his symptoms were not adequately controlled. His medication regimen was changed to include an MAO inhibitor and amitriptyline. Shortly after the change in medication, the patient developed agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyproheptadine

  

The patient’s symptoms of agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors are indicative of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs due to excessive serotonergic activity in the nervous system, usually as a result of combining medications that increase serotonin levels, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. In this case, the combination of sertraline (an SSRI), an MAO inhibitor, and amitriptyline (a TCA) significantly increases serotonin, leading to the development of serotonin syndrome.

 

Symptoms of Serotonin Syndrome: (Mnemonic – RASH D)

 

  • Restlessness
  • Agitation
  • Seizures
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Diarrhea

 

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with serotonin receptor antagonist properties, making it the drug of choice for treating serotonin syndrome. It works by blocking serotonin receptors, thereby reducing the excessive serotonergic activity causing the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine used to manage agitation and seizures but does not directly treat the underlying cause of serotonin syndrome. It is used as supportive therapy but is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. L-carnitine: L-carnitine is a supplement often used in metabolic conditions and does not play a role in treating serotonin syndrome. It has no effect on serotonin levels or receptor activity.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Leucovorin is a form of folic acid used as a rescue agent in methotrexate toxicity and other specific conditions. It has no role in the management of serotonin syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin syndrome can occur when serotonergic drugs are combined, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. The treatment of choice for serotonin syndrome is Cyproheptadine, a serotonin receptor antagonist.

choices.text: Outer wall contains silica and chlorophyll

questions.text: In a case of drowning, the following organism was isolated from the internal organs. What is true regarding this organism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Outer wall contains silica and chlorophyll

 

The organism in question is a diatom, which is a type of unicellular microscopic algae commonly associated with drowning cases. Diatoms have a distinctive cell wall composed of silica, making them resistant to acidic environments. In drowning cases, if the water containing diatoms enters the body, these organisms can travel through the bloodstream and be found in various organs, including the bone marrow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a unicellular bacteria: This statement is incorrect. Diatoms are unicellular algae, not bacteria. They are distinct in their structure and biological function.

 

Option B. Not resistant to acid: This statement is incorrect. Diatoms have a silica-based cell wall, which is resistant to acid, allowing them to survive in harsh environments.

 

Option C. Only present in bone marrow: While diatoms can be found in the bone marrow, especially in cases of drowning, they are not exclusive to this location. They can be distributed to other organs via the circulatory system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diatoms are unicellular algae with a silica-containing outer wall, making them resistant to acid and present in various organs in drowning cases.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was washing her doll with shampoo containing rotenone. Her mother noticed her in an unconscious state. Which is inhibited by the above chemical? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADH dehydrogenase

 

Rotenone is a potent inhibitor of Complex I in the electron transport chain, which is also known as NADH dehydrogenase or NADH oxidoreductase. Complex I is responsible for transferring electrons from NADH to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone), a crucial step in cellular respiration and ATP production. By inhibiting Complex, I, rotenone disrupts the electron transport chain, leading to a significant reduction in ATP synthesis. This inhibition can result in decreased cellular energy and potential cellular damage, which explains the unconscious state observed in the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Succinate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of Complex II in the electron transport chain, which is not affected by rotenone. Complex II facilitates the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, bypassing Complex I, which is why rotenone does not inhibit this step.

 

Option C. Cytochrome C: Cytochrome C is a small heme protein that plays a role in electron transfer between Complex III and Complex IV of the electron transport chain. Rotenone does not affect Cytochrome C, as it acts upstream at Complex I.

 

Option D. Cytochrome oxidase: Also known as Complex IV, this enzyme is responsible for transferring electrons from Cytochrome C to oxygen, the final electron acceptor. Inhibitors of Complex IV include cyanide and carbon monoxide, not rotenone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotenone specifically inhibits Complex I also known as NADH CoQ oxidoreductase (NADH dehydrogenase) in the electron transport chain, blocking electron flow and ATP production.

questions.text: Which of the following requires the most energy to assimilate?
A person with suspected marijuana consumption is brought by the police for urine drug testing. He claims single use of marijuana at a party. Up to how many days can the drug be detected in his urine?
In a case of RTA (Road Traffic Accident), a person has died. Who can order an autopsy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Police Officer


In cases of deaths such as those resulting from road traffic accidents, the decision to conduct an autopsy is made by the Investigating Officer (IO), typically a Police Officer. The Police Officer is responsible for the inquest, which involves examining the circumstances of the death and deciding whether an autopsy is necessary to determine the cause of death. While the actual conduction of the autopsy is performed by a forensic doctor, the authorization comes from the Police Officer handling the case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Public Prosecutor: The Public Prosecutor is involved in legal proceedings but does not have the authority to order an autopsy. Their role begins after the investigation and autopsy have been conducted and evidence is gathered.

 

Option B. Defendant Lawyer: The Defendant Lawyer represents the accused in legal proceedings and has no authority to order an autopsy. Their role is strictly legal defense, not investigative.

 

Option D. Forensic Medicine Doctor: The Forensic Medicine Doctor conducts the autopsy but does not have the authority to order one. They act upon the request of the Investigating Officer who is in charge of the case.

 

Educational Objective:


The Police Officer, specifically the Investigating Officer, has the authority to order an autopsy in cases of unexplained or suspicious deaths, such as those resulting from a road traffic accident.

questions.text: A patient consumed a toxic substance and presented with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hypocalcemia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethylene Glycol

 

Ethylene glycol is a toxic substance commonly found in antifreeze. When ingested, it is metabolized into toxic metabolites, including oxalic acid. Oxalic acid binds to calcium in the blood, forming calcium oxalate crystals, which leads to hypocalcemia—a significant clue in diagnosing ethylene glycol poisoning. Additionally, ethylene glycol poisoning often presents with symptoms like tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension, as seen in this case.

 

Hypocalcemia is a critical diagnostic feature because it specifically points toward ethylene glycol ingestion compared to other toxic substances. Early recognition and treatment are essential to prevent severe complications, including kidney failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron poisoning typically presents with gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain) and systemic toxicity such as metabolic acidosis. Hypocalcemia is not a hallmark feature of iron poisoning, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Methanol: Methanol poisoning can cause metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances ("snowfield" vision), and central nervous system depression. Hypocalcemia is not commonly associated with methanol toxicity, which makes this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin toxicity commonly presents with gastrointestinal symptoms, confusion, visual changes, and arrhythmias. While it can cause hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia is not a feature of digoxin poisoning, eliminating this option as the Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by hypocalcemia due to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals and presents with symptoms such as tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension.

questions.text: A pregnant woman undergoes USG examination. She is found to have twins, but one-month age gap in twins on USG scan. What is this phenomenon called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superfetation

 

Superfetation is a rare phenomenon where a second pregnancy occurs while a woman is already pregnant, resulting in twins with different ages. This happens due to two separate acts of intercourse occurring in two different menstrual cycles, leading to two embryos of different gestational ages. In superfetation, one baby is conceived during one cycle, and another baby is conceived in a subsequent cycle, often resulting in a noticeable size difference between the two babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Superfecundation: Superfecundation also involves twins and separate acts of intercourse; however, it occurs within the same menstrual cycle. This means that two ova are fertilized at or near the same time, leading to twins of the same gestational age and size. Unlike superfetation, the twins are conceived during the same cycle.

 

Option C. Illegitimate child: This term refers to a child born outside of marriage and is not related to the phenomenon of having twins with different ages. It does not describe a medical condition or scenario of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Suppositious child: This term generally refers to a child that is wrongly supposed or believed to belong to a particular family. It is not relevant to the context of twins with a one-month age gap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfetation is characterized by the occurrence of two separate pregnancies in different menstrual cycles, leading to twins of different gestational ages.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl, a victim of rape, presents at 22 weeks for abortion. What advice will you give her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTP can be done till 24 weeks

 

The MTP Act of 2021 in India allows for abortions b/w 20- 24 weeks in specific cases, including:

 

  • Rape or sexual assault: The girl in the question is a victim of rape, which falls under this category.
  • Risk to maternal life or Disability: If continuing the pregnancy poses a significant risk to the mother's health or life.
  • Substantial fetal anomaly: If the fetus has severe abnormalities incompatible with life or causing significant disability.
  • Minors: The girl is 14 years old, making her a minor, and the law provides special considerations for them.
  • Change in marital status or humanitarian grounds: These are additional situations where MTP may be considered up to 24 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks: This is incorrect. While the general limit for MTP is 20 weeks, certain circumstances, like rape, allow for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option C. MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk: This is partially correct. While risk to the mother's life is a valid reason, it's not the only one. Rape is also a valid indication for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option D. MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly: Again, this is partially correct. Substantial fetal anomaly is one reason, but rape is another valid reason for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, under the MTP Act of 2021:

questions.text: An investigator is studying the structure of the amino-terminal of the Huntingtin protein using x-ray crystallography. The terminal region is determined to have an α-helix conformation. Which of the following forces is most likely responsible for maintaining this conformation?
A patient came to the emergency room with severe pain in the abdomen. Serum triglyceride level was 1500 mg/dL. Identify the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apo CII

 

The clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain and extremely elevated triglyceride levels (1500 mg/dL) suggests acute pancreatitis secondary to hypertriglyceridemia, commonly seen in Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia. This condition is characterized by a defect in the lipoprotein lipase (LPL) enzyme or its activator, Apo CII. Apo CII is essential for the activation of LPL, which breaks down triglycerides in the blood. A deficiency or defect in Apo CII prevents this activation, leading to the accumulation of triglycerides and increased risk of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo B 48: This apolipoprotein is essential for the formation of chylomicrons but does not play a role in lipase activation or triglyceride breakdown. Defects in Apo B 48 do not cause elevated triglyceride levels seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Apo B 100: Apo B 100 is critical for the formation of LDL and VLDL particles but does not contribute directly to triglyceride metabolism or cause the acute elevation of triglycerides leading to pancreatitis.

 

Option D. LDL receptor: Defects in LDL receptors are associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, leading to elevated LDL cholesterol levels, not triglycerides. It does not contribute to the type of severe hypertriglyceridemia seen in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia, presenting with high triglycerides and abdominal pain, is often due to a defect in lipoprotein lipase or its activator, Apo CII.

questions.text: A dead body shows the following finding as in the image. What is the case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Smothering

 

The image shows signs consistent with smothering, a form of asphyxiation where the airflow is blocked by an external force, usually involving the face or mouth, preventing the person from breathing. In smothering, injuries are typically seen on the face rather than the neck. There may be signs of trauma around the mouth and nose, indicating forceful application, such as abrasions or bruising, which is evident in the provided image. This physical evidence strongly points to smothering as the cause of death, where force is applied directly to the face, blocking the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hanging: Hanging involves the compression of the neck due to the body’s weight pulling down on a ligature around the neck, leading to strangulation and neck injuries. The primary injury site is the neck, not the face, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Gagging: Gagging involves inserting a foreign object into the mouth, typically to prevent the person from making noise rather than to kill. Although accidental asphyxia can occur if the object obstructs the airway deeply, injuries are usually minimal and not the result of direct trauma like in smothering. Gagging does not cause the kind of facial trauma visible in the image.

 

Option C. Garrotting: Garrotting is a form of strangulation where the neck is compressed with a ligature and twisted with a lever, leading to neck injuries. This method results in visible trauma around the neck, not the face. Since the injuries shown are facial, garrotting is not the Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smothering is characterized by facial injuries resulting from forceful application that obstructs breathing, distinguishing it from neck compression injuries seen in hanging or garrotting.

questions.text: A man wears female heels and a female dress to get sexual arousal. He is not interested in males. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic Fetishism

 

Transvestic Fetishism is a condition where an individual wears clothing of the opposite sex primarily to achieve sexual arousal. The key aspect of this disorder is the act of cross-dressing for the purpose of sexual gratification, not because of a desire to be of the opposite gender or any issues with gender identity. The patient described is not interested in males and is engaging in cross-dressing purely for sexual arousal, fitting the diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender Dysphoria involves a conflict between an individual’s biological sex and their gender identity, such as a biologically male person identifying as female or vice versa. There is no indication in this case of any gender identity issues; the patient cross-dresses purely for sexual arousal.

 

Option C. Homosexuality: Homosexuality refers to a sexual orientation characterized by attraction to individuals of the same sex. The scenario explicitly states that the man is not interested in males, ruling out homosexuality as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is the act of gaining sexual pleasure from watching others when they are naked or engaged in sexual activity, usually without their knowledge or consent. There is no element of voyeuristic behavior described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic Fetishism is characterized by cross-dressing for sexual arousal without any associated desire to change one’s gender or sexual orientation.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to several months of fatigue and difficulty walking. She ambulates normally at first but rapidly becomes weak and tired. Examination shows mildly decreased power in all extremities but no ataxia. Cardiac auscultation reveals a 1/6 systolic murmur and an S3 gallop. Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum chemistry

  • Glucose: 37 mg/dL
  • Creatine kinase: 304 U/L

Urinalysis

  • Protein: none
  • Glucose: negative
  • Ketones: negative
  • Leukocyte esterase: negative
  • Nitrites: negative

Muscle biopsy shows a very low carnitine content. This patient most likely has deficient synthesis of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetoacetate

 

Systemic carnitine deficiency blocks transport of long-chain fatty acyl-CoA into mitochondria, preventing β-oxidation. Without β-oxidation, the liver cannot generate acetyl-CoA for ketogenesis, causing hypoketotic hypoglycemia and low muscle energy. Therefore ketone bodies (e.g., acetoacetate) are deficient despite fasting hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arachidonic acid: Not dependent on carnitine transport; it is a 20:4 ω-6 fatty acid derived from linoleic acid and incorporated into membrane phospholipids. Carnitine deficiency impairs fatty acid oxidation/ketogenesis, not ω-6 PUFA synthesis.

 

Option C. Lactate: Produced via anaerobic glycolysis; its synthesis does not require mitochondrial fatty acid entry. Carnitine deficiency typically causes hypoketotic hypoglycemia, not impaired lactate production.

 

Option D. Palmitate: Formed by cytosolic fatty acid synthase from acetyl-CoA and malonyl-CoA; synthesis does not need carnitine. Carnitine is required for mitochondrial oxidation of palmitate, not for its synthesis.

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of the father’s death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby might not be their son’s, but DNA came positive. What is such a child called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posthumous child

 

A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of either parent. In this scenario, the child was born 8 months after the father's death, which fits the definition of a posthumous child. The grandparents doubted the child’s legitimacy, but DNA testing confirmed the biological connection, validating the child's status as the deceased father's offspring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suppositious child: A suppositious child is a term used to describe a fraudulent or fake child who is falsely presented as an heir, often to claim property or inheritance. This does not apply in this case because the DNA test confirmed the child’s legitimacy as the biological offspring.

 

Option B. Fictitious child: A fictitious child is purely an imaginary or invented figure that does not exist in reality, often found in literature or imagination. This term is unrelated to the case as it refers to nonexistent entities, unlike the real, biologically confirmed child in question.

 

Option D. Illegitimate child: An illegitimate child is one born outside of marriage or not legally recognized as belonging to the mother's husband. In this case, the DNA test confirmed that the child is indeed the biological offspring of the deceased father, making the term irrelevant here.

 

Educational Objective:


A posthumous child is one born after the death of a parent, as seen in this scenario where the child was born 8 months after the father's death.

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry mouth, dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, and delirium. What could be the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dhatura


Dhatura poisoning is associated with anticholinergic toxidrome, which presents with features such as dry mouth, dilated pupils, dry skin, slurred speech, and delirium. Anticholinergic substances like Dhatura inhibit the action of acetylcholine, leading to reduced secretions, dilated pupils, and central nervous system effects like confusion and delirium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid and falls under the category of CNS depressants. Opioids typically cause pupil constriction (miosis), not dilation, and do not produce dry skin or dry mouth, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol, especially in the early stages, may cause pupil dilation but usually presents with wet skin and slurred speech due to CNS depression, not dry features. Dry skin and mouth are not characteristic of alcohol intoxication, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Cocaine is a sympathomimetic agent, which can cause pupil dilation but does not cause dry mouth or dry skin. Cocaine typically increases body secretions rather than reducing them, so this does not fit the anticholinergic profile described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:


Dhatura poisoning exhibits an anticholinergic toxidrome characterized by dry mouth, dry skin, dilated pupils, and altered mental status, distinguishing it from other toxidromes.

questions.text: If a woman is undergoing MTP after 24 weeks of gestation due to congenital anomaly in the fetus, whose presence is not required for authorization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lawyer

 

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) regulations require authorization by a medical board when a pregnancy extends beyond 24 weeks, particularly in cases involving serious congenital anomalies. The board typically comprises a gynecologist, pediatrician, and sonologist—professionals whose expertise is crucial in assessing the risks and conditions related to both the pregnancy and the identified anomaly.

 

A lawyer is not part of this medical board and does not play a role in authorizing MTP, as the decision is purely based on medical assessment rather than legal consultation. The presence of a lawyer is not necessary because the authorization process focuses on the medical justification and safety considerations rather than legal arguments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetrician: The obstetrician is involved in the care of the pregnant woman and is often part of the medical decision-making team, especially when dealing with complex or high-risk pregnancies.

 

Option C. Pediatrician: Pediatricians are essential members of the medical board because they provide expertise on the potential outcomes for the fetus, especially in cases involving congenital anomalies that could impact the fetus's viability or quality of life.

 

Option D. Sonologist: The sonologist's role is crucial as they specialize in ultrasound and imaging, providing detailed assessments of the fetus's condition. Their input is vital in confirming congenital anomalies and guiding the medical board’s decision-making process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MTP after 24 weeks for congenital anomalies, the medical board's authorization is required and comprises a gynecologist, pediatrician, and sonologist. A lawyer’s presence is not required for this authorization process.

questions.text: Which of the following minerals help with Insulin Sensitivity?

A 24-year-old woman with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections comes to the physician with dysuria and increased urinary frequency. Her urine culture grows colonies of Gram-negative bacteria. The bacteria are isolated and placed in a growth-enhancing nutrient solution, where they undergo rapid cellular division. As they are actively dividing, the bacterial cells are lysed, and their DNA is extracted and purified. Analysis of the partially replicated DNA fragments shows the presence of uracil. This finding is most likely mediated by which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primase

 

The presence of uracil in partially replicated bacterial DNA indicates the presence of RNA primers, which are synthesized by the enzyme primase. Primase is a DNA-dependent RNA polymerase that lays down short RNA segments complementary to the DNA template, providing a free 3′-OH group for DNA polymerase III to begin DNA strand synthesis. The uracil in these primers confirms that they are RNA, since DNA contains thymine instead of uracil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA ligase: Incorrect. DNA ligase joins Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand by sealing the nicks between adjacent DNA fragments after primer removal. 

 

Option B. DNA polymerase I: Incorrect. DNA polymerase I removes the RNA primers made by primase and replaces them with DNA nucleotides, so it actually eliminates uracil-containing regions rather than creating them.

 

Option C. DNA polymerase III: Incorrect. DNA polymerase III elongates the new DNA strand by adding deoxyribonucleotides (with thymine) to the primer.

questions.text: Which is correct about isoenzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Catalyse the same reaction.

 

Isoenzymes (isozymes) are different molecular forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same biochemical reaction but differ in their amino acid sequence, kinetic properties (Km, Vmax), and tissue distribution. They are encoded by different genes and often serve as tissue-specific markers, such as LDH, CK, and ALP isoenzymes. Despite structural differences, their catalytic activity on the substrate remains identical. Eg: LDH

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Same action with similar kinetics: Incorrect. Although isoenzymes catalyze the same reaction (same action), their kinetic properties differ — for example, they have different affinities for substrates and vary in regulation and optimum conditions.

 

Option B. Same quaternary structure: Incorrect. Isoenzymes can have different quaternary structures (subunit composition). For instance, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) has five isoenzymes made up of varying combinations of H and M subunits, giving them distinct structures.

 

Option D. Cannot be separated from each other on Electrophoresis: Incorrect. Isoenzymes can be separated by electrophoresis because of differences in their charge and structure. This property is clinically useful in identifying tissue-specific damage (e.g., LDH or CK isoenzyme patterns).
